qualities.name: Functional Suitability
qualities.description: Degree to which a product or system provides functions that meet stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions.
qualities.examples: bounded contexts, data structures, API design, domain events, algorithms, testing

ideation.assessment: AI is well-suited for exploring and generating ideas for features and functionality. The green rating reflects the high potential of current tools, though full automation is still a distant goal.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous requirements engineering
limitation.description: AI cannot independently understand business needs and generate a complete and correct set of requirements without human oversight.
limitation.assessment: This is a fundamental limitation. While AI can assist in requirements engineering, it currently lacks the deep domain understanding and contextual awareness to perform this task autonomously.

practice.name: AI-assisted requirements engineering and ideation
practice.description: AI assists with brainstorming, requirements elicitation, use case generation, and formal specification. Large Language Models can generate ideas, explore problem facets, create scenarios including edge cases, and help automate formal specifications. Capabilities range from effective brainstorming (high maturity) to emerging formal specification support.
practice.assessment: AI is strong at brainstorming and generating wide-ranging ideas, with excellent use case and scenario generation including edge cases. Formal specification assistance is emerging but requires human expertise. Quality depends on prompt quality and domain expert validation.

tools.name: ChatGPT
tools.description: LLM tool for brainstorming and requirements elicitation
tools.assessment: Widely adopted tool for AI-assisted ideation and requirements work.

tools.name: Google Gemini
tools.description: LLM tool for brainstorming and requirements elicitation
tools.assessment: Widely adopted tool for AI-assisted ideation and requirements work.

planning.assessment: AI is showing promise in this area, but it's still an emerging capability. The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can assist with planning tasks, it cannot yet handle the full complexity and strategic thinking required for project planning.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous project planning
limitation.description: AI cannot create a complete project plan, including architecture, timelines, and resource allocation, with minimal human input.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. While AI can assist with specific planning tasks, it cannot yet handle the full complexity and strategic thinking required for project planning.

practice.name: AI-assisted agile planning and estimation
practice.description: AI helps generate and refine user stories from high-level features, breaks down epics, ensures format consistency, and assists with task breakdown and effort estimation. While showing promise, it requires human oversight for effective user stories and accurate estimates.
practice.assessment: AI is emerging in this area with useful capabilities for story generation and task breakdown. However, it often lacks deep understanding of user needs and business context. Estimates should be used as guidance alongside traditional methods, requiring validation from domain experts.

tools.name: Jira
tools.description: Project management tool with AI-powered features for user story generation
tools.assessment: Mature tool with emerging AI capabilities for agile planning.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can generate code, it is not yet capable of building complete, complex applications. The generated code needs to be carefully reviewed and tested by developers.

limitation.name: Limited fully autonomous code generation
limitation.description: AI cannot write a complete, production-ready application from a set of requirements without significant human involvement.
limitation.assessment: This is the holy grail of AI in software development, but it is still a long way off. While AI can generate code snippets and simple applications, it cannot yet handle the complexity and creativity required to build large, real-world systems.

practice.name: AI-powered code and test generation
practice.description: AI generates code from natural language prompts, creates test cases from code and requirements, generates privacy-safe synthetic test data, and assists with BDD scenario creation. Capabilities span from mature synthetic data generation to emerging BDD support, accelerating development and testing workflows.
practice.assessment: AI shows strong capabilities in code generation and test data synthesis, with emerging effectiveness in test case and BDD scenario generation. While powerful for accelerating development, generated code requires careful review for correctness, security, and performance. Synthetic data maintains statistical properties but may miss edge cases.

tools.name: GitHub Copilot
tools.description: AI-powered code completion and generation tool
tools.assessment: Widely adopted tool that significantly accelerates code writing but requires developer oversight.

tools.name: Amazon CodeWhisperer
tools.description: AI-powered code completion and generation tool
tools.assessment: Mature tool with strong AWS integration for code generation.

tools.name: Mostly AI
tools.assessment: Mature platform for generating privacy-safe test data.

tools.name: Tonic.ai
tools.assessment: Production-ready tool for test data generation with privacy compliance.

tools.name: Gretel.ai
tools.assessment: Advanced synthetic data platform with strong privacy guarantees.

tools.name: Cucumber
tools.description: BDD framework with emerging AI assistance
tools.assessment: Established BDD tool with growing AI integration capabilities.

tools.name: SpecFlow
tools.description: BDD framework for .NET with AI support
tools.assessment: Mature BDD tool for .NET with emerging AI features.

qualities.name: Performance Efficiency
qualities.description: The performance of a system in relation to the amount of resources it consumes under specified conditions.
qualities.examples: caching, scaling, connection pooling, queuing, data indexing, data sharding, lazy loading

ideation.assessment: AI is very effective at identifying common performance anti-patterns and suggesting well-known optimization techniques. The green rating reflects the high potential of current tools.

limitation.name: Limited predictive performance modeling
limitation.description: AI cannot accurately predict the performance of a complex system before it is built across all scenarios.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging research problem. While AI can provide some high-level estimates, accurately modeling the performance of a complex system is beyond the current state of the art.

practice.name: AI-powered performance optimization and query analysis
practice.description: AI analyzes application code and database queries to identify performance anti-patterns, suggest optimizations like efficient algorithms and data structures, recommend indexes, detect N+1 queries, and propose query rewrites. Particularly strong for database query optimization with actionable recommendations.
practice.assessment: AI excels at identifying common performance issues and suggesting well-known optimization techniques. Particularly effective for database query analysis, detecting missing indexes and inefficient joins. Provides valuable insights during design phase, though recommendations should be validated in context.

tools.name: EverSQL
tools.assessment: Mature tool for automated query analysis and optimization recommendations.

tools.name: Dexter
tools.assessment: Production-ready tool for PostgreSQL index recommendations.

tools.name: AWS Performance Insights
tools.description: Database performance monitoring and tuning service
tools.assessment: Mature AWS service for database performance analysis.

planning.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can assist with capacity planning, it often lacks the deep understanding of the system's specific workload and business context to make optimal decisions.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous capacity planning
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically determine the optimal resource allocation for a system to meet its performance goals without human insight.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging task for AI. While AI can assist with capacity planning, it often lacks the deep understanding of the system's specific workload and business context to make optimal decisions.

practice.name: AI-assisted capacity planning and load testing
practice.description: AI analyzes historical performance data to predict future resource needs, assists with capacity planning, and generates realistic load testing scenarios based on production traffic patterns. Emerging capability that requires validation and domain expertise.
practice.assessment: AI provides useful insights for capacity planning and can identify traffic patterns for load testing. However, accuracy depends heavily on training data quality and quantity. Creating truly representative load tests requires domain expertise. Predictions and scenarios should guide rather than replace traditional planning methods.

tools.name: k6
tools.description: Modern load testing tool with AI-enhanced scenario generation
tools.assessment: Mature open-source load testing tool with growing AI capabilities.

tools.name: LoadNinja
tools.assessment: Commercial load testing platform with AI-powered insights.

tools.name: Flood.io
tools.assessment: Established platform for distributed performance testing.

execution.assessment: The red rating reflects the fact that while AI can suggest performance optimizations, automatically implementing and verifying them without causing regressions is a very difficult problem.

limitation.name: Limited automated performance tuning
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically identify and fix performance bottlenecks in real-time without risk of introducing regressions.
limitation.assessment: This is still a research topic. While AI can suggest performance optimizations, automatically implementing and verifying them without causing regressions is a very difficult problem. The complexity and dynamism of modern software systems make this a major challenge for AI.

practice.name: AI-powered performance monitoring and resource optimization
practice.description: AI continuously monitors application performance, detects anomalies, identifies root causes, predicts performance degradation, analyzes resource utilization patterns, and recommends right-sizing and cost optimizations while maintaining SLAs. Mature capability for cloud environments with reliable optimization recommendations.
practice.assessment: AI excels at anomaly detection, correlation, and resource optimization in cloud environments. APM tools are rapidly maturing with strong capabilities, though complex performance issues still require human interpretation. Resource optimization recommendations are reliable but require careful validation and gradual rollout. Automated remediation remains limited.

tools.name: Dynatrace
tools.assessment: Market-leading APM with advanced AI capabilities for anomaly detection.

tools.name: New Relic
tools.assessment: Mature observability platform with strong AI-driven analytics.

tools.name: Datadog
tools.description: Monitoring and analytics platform with AI features
tools.assessment: Widely adopted monitoring platform with AI-powered alerting and analysis.

tools.name: AWS Compute Optimizer
tools.description: Machine learning service for EC2 right-sizing
tools.assessment: Production-ready AWS service for cost optimization recommendations.

tools.name: Google Cloud Recommender
tools.assessment: Mature GCP service for infrastructure optimization.

tools.name: Azure Advisor
tools.description: Personalized cloud consultant with optimization recommendations
tools.assessment: Azure's mature recommendation service for cost and performance.

qualities.name: Compatibility
qualities.description: Degree to which a product or system can exchange information with other products or systems and perform its required functions while sharing the same hardware or software environment.
qualities.examples: API governance, schema evolution, integrations, encodings, plugins, versioning

ideation.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can be a useful assistant in this area, it often lacks the deep understanding of the specific business needs and technical constraints to design a truly effective API.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous integration design
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically design the optimal integration strategy for a set of systems without understanding business context.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the semantics of the data being exchanged and the business processes that the integration is intended to support.

practice.name: API design and integration strategy
practice.description: AI can suggest API designs and integration strategies based on best practices and analysis of existing systems.
practice.assessment: AI can be a useful assistant in this area, but it often lacks the deep understanding of the specific business needs and technical constraints to design a truly effective API. Human expertise is still essential.

planning.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can automate some of the tedious work of data mapping, it often struggles with complex transformations and requires human oversight.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous data mapping and transformation
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically map data between different systems and generate the necessary transformations for complex schemas.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging task for AI, especially when the data models are complex and there is a need for semantic mapping.

practice.name: AI-assisted API design and data mapping
practice.description: AI helps map data between systems, generate transformations, suggest RESTful API designs, generate OpenAPI specifications from code, and create comprehensive API documentation with examples. Effective at standardizing patterns and generating documentation, though complex transformations and business-aligned API design require human expertise.
practice.assessment: AI can automate tedious data mapping work and standardize API design patterns effectively. However, it struggles with complex semantic transformations and requires human oversight. Designing truly developer-friendly APIs that meet business needs requires human expertise and domain knowledge.

tools.name: Swagger
tools.assessment: Industry-standard tool for API design and documentation with growing AI features.

tools.name: Postman
tools.assessment: Widely adopted API platform with AI-assisted testing and documentation.

tools.name: Stoplight
tools.assessment: Modern API design tool with collaborative features.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can generate code snippets for integrations, it's not yet capable of handling the full complexity of building and testing robust integrations.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous integration testing
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically generate and execute a comprehensive set of integration tests without understanding business processes.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the business processes that the integration is intended to support and the ability to generate realistic test data.

practice.name: AI-powered integration development and testing
practice.description: AI generates code for API connections and data processing, creates API test cases, validates contracts, detects breaking changes, and suggests backward-compatible evolution strategies. Excels at generating comprehensive test suites and detecting schema changes, though understanding business logic constraints requires human input.
practice.assessment: AI can generate integration code snippets and boilerplate effectively, but cannot handle full complexity of robust integrations. Strong at generating comprehensive API test suites and contract validation. Developers need to carefully review and test generated code, especially for business logic constraints.

tools.name: GitHub Copilot
tools.description: AI-powered code completion for integration code
tools.assessment: Widely adopted for generating integration boilerplate and API client code.

tools.name: Amazon CodeWhisperer
tools.description: AI code generator with AWS integration expertise
tools.assessment: Strong tool for AWS integration code generation.

tools.name: Postman
tools.description: API testing platform with AI-powered test generation
tools.assessment: Mature tool for API testing and contract validation.

tools.name: Katalon
tools.description: Test automation platform with API testing
tools.assessment: Comprehensive testing platform with AI-enhanced capabilities.

tools.name: Testim
tools.assessment: Modern testing tool with machine learning-based test maintenance.

qualities.name: Interaction Capability
qualities.description: Degree to which a product can be used by specified users to achieve goals with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction.
qualities.examples: UI prototypes, screen flows, theming, localization, validation, state management

ideation.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can be a great way to quickly explore different design ideas, it is not a replacement for a human designer.

limitation.name: Limited empathetic UI design
limitation.description: AI cannot understand user emotions and design a UI that is not only usable but also enjoyable and engaging.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of human psychology and the ability to reason about emotions.

practice.name: Generating UI mockups and user flows
practice.description: These tools can generate UI mockups and user flows from text prompts or hand-drawn sketches.
practice.assessment: These tools can be a great way to quickly explore different design ideas, but they are not a replacement for a human designer. The generated designs often lack the polish and user-centric focus of a professionally designed UI.

tools.name: Uizard
tools.assessment: Rapid prototyping tool for generating UI mockups from descriptions.

tools.name: Galileo AI
tools.assessment: Advanced tool for generating UI designs from natural language.

planning.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can provide valuable insights, it's not yet capable of understanding the full context of user behavior and motivations.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous usability testing
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically conduct usability tests and provide a comprehensive report on the user experience without human observation.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging task for AI. While AI can assist with usability testing, it cannot yet replace human testers who can provide rich, qualitative feedback on the user experience.

practice.name: AI-powered usability analysis and experimentation
practice.description: AI analyzes user behavior during usability tests to identify pain points, generates user personas, automatically allocates traffic to experiments, determines statistical significance, and suggests winning variations based on multi-variant testing. Particularly mature for A/B testing and statistical analysis.
practice.assessment: AI excels at statistical analysis and optimization for A/B testing, significantly reducing time to insights. However, understanding full context of user behavior and motivations remains limited. Human interpretation is essential for usability insights, and business context is required for experiment interpretation.

tools.name: Optimizely
tools.assessment: Market-leading platform for AI-driven experimentation.

tools.name: VWO
tools.description: A/B testing and conversion optimization platform
tools.assessment: Mature platform for experience optimization with AI insights.

tools.name: Google Optimize
tools.assessment: Well-integrated experimentation tool with Google Analytics.

execution.assessment: The green rating reflects the fact that AI-powered tools can significantly accelerate UI development by generating code from designs. However, the generated code may still need to be tweaked by developers.

limitation.name: Limited self-optimizing UIs
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically adapt the UI to the needs of individual users in real-time.
limitation.assessment: This is a promising area for AI, but it is still in its early stages. While there are some examples of self-optimizing UIs, they are not yet widely used.

practice.name: AI-powered UI development and quality assurance
practice.description: AI automatically generates UI code from design files, performs visual regression testing using computer vision to detect unintended changes while filtering acceptable variations, and scans for WCAG compliance issues with accessibility fix suggestions. Highly mature for code generation and visual testing, very effective for technical accessibility violations.
practice.assessment: This is a mature and highly effective area for AI. Code generation from designs is widely used and produces high-quality output, though may need developer refinement. Visual AI excels at detecting pixel-level changes while intelligently filtering false positives. Accessibility testing effectively catches technical violations, but actual user experience evaluation requires human testing.

tools.name: Figma
tools.description: Design tool with AI-powered code generation plugins
tools.assessment: Industry-standard design tool with robust code export capabilities.

tools.name: Anima
tools.assessment: Specialized tool for converting designs to production code.

tools.name: Applitools
tools.assessment: Market leader in AI-powered visual testing with advanced diff algorithms.

tools.name: Percy
tools.assessment: Widely adopted visual regression testing tool.

tools.name: Chromatic
tools.assessment: Popular visual testing tool integrated with component libraries.

tools.name: Axe
tools.assessment: Industry-standard accessibility testing tool with high accuracy.

tools.name: WAVE
tools.assessment: Comprehensive accessibility checker with browser integration.

tools.name: AccessiBe
tools.assessment: Automated accessibility remediation with AI-driven fixes.

qualities.name: Reliability
qualities.description: Degree to which a system performs specified functions under specified conditions for a certain period.
qualities.examples: redundancy, monitoring, circuit breaker, chaos monkey, bulkheads

ideation.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can be a useful tool for identifying potential reliability issues, it often lacks the deep understanding of the system's specific requirements to suggest the most appropriate solutions.

limitation.name: Limited proactive reliability engineering
limitation.description: AI cannot predict and prevent reliability issues before they occur without deep system knowledge.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the system's architecture, workload, and operating environment.

practice.name: AI-assisted reliability design and failure prediction
practice.description: AI analyzes system architecture to suggest reliability patterns like redundancy and failover, and analyzes historical failure patterns and system metrics to predict potential failure modes and suggest preventive measures. Emerging but promising capability for proactive intervention.
practice.assessment: AI is useful for identifying potential reliability issues and failure pattern recognition. However, it often lacks deep understanding of system-specific requirements for optimal solutions. Failure prediction accuracy improves significantly with quality training data, enabling proactive interventions.

planning.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can generate a large number of test cases, it often struggles to create the most effective ones for uncovering reliability issues.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous reliability testing
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically generate and execute a comprehensive set of reliability tests without understanding failure modes.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the system's failure modes and the ability to generate realistic test scenarios.

practice.name: Creating reliability testing plans and defining recovery procedures
practice.description: AI can generate test cases to verify the reliability of a system and help to define recovery procedures.
practice.assessment: This is an emerging area for AI. While AI can generate a large number of test cases, it often struggles to create the most effective ones for uncovering reliability issues.

execution.assessment: The red rating reflects the fact that while tools like ChaosMonkey can automate failure injection, using AI to intelligently guide the process and analyze the results is still in its early stages.

limitation.name: Limited self-healing systems
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically detect and recover from failures without human intervention in most scenarios.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging research problem. While there are some examples of self-healing systems, they are not yet widely used and are often limited to specific types of failures.

practice.name: AI-powered reliability operations and incident response
practice.description: AI automates failure injection and resilience verification, correlates alerts to reduce noise, predicts incidents, suggests root causes across distributed systems by analyzing logs/metrics/traces, and can trigger remediation workflows. Rapidly evolving for incident management but early stage for chaos engineering.
practice.assessment: AI significantly reduces alert fatigue and speeds up incident response, with growing effectiveness at narrowing root causes in complex distributed systems. However, chaos engineering with AI is very challenging and still early stage. Fully automated remediation is limited to simple scenarios, and implementing fixes requires human expertise and validation.

tools.name: Gremlin
tools.assessment: Production-ready platform for controlled failure injection.

tools.name: ChaosMonkey
tools.assessment: Open-source tool for random instance termination testing.

tools.name: PagerDuty
tools.description: Incident response platform with AI features
tools.assessment: Mature incident management platform with ML-powered alert grouping.

tools.name: BigPanda
tools.assessment: AI-driven alert correlation and incident automation.

tools.name: Moogsoft
tools.assessment: AIOps platform focused on noise reduction and root cause analysis.

tools.name: Splunk
tools.assessment: Industry-leading log analysis platform with ML capabilities.

tools.name: LogicMonitor
tools.assessment: Comprehensive monitoring platform with anomaly detection.

tools.name: Elastic
tools.description: Search and analytics platform with ML
tools.assessment: Popular observability stack with machine learning features.

qualities.name: Security
qualities.description: How well a product or system protects information and data, ensuring that access is appropriate to the authorization levels of users or other systems.
qualities.examples: authorization, roles, rights, tokens, encryption, auditing, input validation

ideation.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can be a useful assistant in this area, it's not yet capable of replacing human security experts.

limitation.name: Limited proactive threat modeling
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically identify and assess all potential security threats to a system without understanding attacker motivations.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the threat landscape and the ability to reason about the attacker's motivations and capabilities.

practice.name: AI-assisted threat modeling and security architecture
practice.description: AI helps identify potential security threats, suggests security requirements and controls, analyzes architecture diagrams, identifies trust boundaries, and recommends threat mitigations based on common attack patterns. Provides valuable pattern matching but requires human expertise for organization-specific context.
practice.assessment: AI is a useful assistant for identifying threats and suggesting standard security controls through pattern matching against known threats. However, it cannot replace human security experts who understand the threat landscape, organization-specific risk appetite, and system-specific context.

tools.name: IriusRisk
tools.assessment: Mature tool for collaborative threat modeling with AI suggestions.

tools.name: ThreatModeler
tools.assessment: Comprehensive platform for security architecture review.

planning.assessment: The red rating reflects the fact that creating a comprehensive security plan is a strategic task that requires a level of critical thinking and risk assessment that AI currently lacks.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous security planning
limitation.description: AI cannot create a comprehensive security plan, including security architecture, policies, and procedures without strategic oversight.
limitation.assessment: This is a strategic task that requires a level of critical thinking and risk assessment that AI currently lacks. While AI can provide input to the process, it cannot be responsible for creating the overall security plan.

practice.name: Security planning
practice.description: Creating comprehensive security plans including architecture, policies, and procedures requires strategic thinking and risk assessment beyond current AI capabilities.
practice.assessment: This is a strategic task requiring critical thinking and risk assessment that AI currently lacks. AI can provide input, but cannot be responsible for overall security planning.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the tension between the powerful tools that exist today and the ultimate goal of bullet-proof security, which remains elusive.

limitation.name: No guarantee of complete security
limitation.description: AI cannot guarantee a system is free from all security vulnerabilities given the evolving threat landscape.
limitation.assessment: This is an extremely challenging goal. The ever-evolving nature of security threats and the complexity of modern software systems make it impossible to guarantee 100% security.

practice.name: AI-powered security testing and vulnerability management
practice.description: AI-powered tools automatically scan for vulnerabilities, patch security issues, rewrite insecure code, keep dependencies updated, enhance SAST/DAST with reduced false positives and prioritization, and detect/remediate exposed secrets with high accuracy. Mature capabilities for dependency management and secrets detection, strong for vulnerability scanning with context-aware fixes.
practice.assessment: AI significantly improves security through automation of vulnerability scanning, dependency updates, and secrets detection with low false positive rates. Enhanced SAST/DAST provides actionable remediation guidance with improved signal-to-noise ratio. However, tools can only address known vulnerabilities and novel patterns may be missed. Human oversight remains essential as these are not silver bullets.

tools.name: Google CodeMender
tools.description: AI agent for automated vulnerability fixing
tools.assessment: Advanced tool for automatically patching security vulnerabilities.

tools.name: GitHub Dependabot
tools.description: Automated dependency updates and security alerts
tools.assessment: Industry-standard tool for dependency management with excellent GitHub integration.

tools.name: Renovate
tools.assessment: Highly configurable dependency management with multi-platform support.

tools.name: Snyk
tools.assessment: Comprehensive security platform with AI-powered vulnerability prioritization.

tools.name: Checkmarx
tools.assessment: Enterprise-grade SAST/DAST with AI-enhanced scanning.

tools.name: Semgrep
tools.assessment: Fast, customizable SAST tool with pattern matching.

tools.name: GitGuardian
tools.assessment: Leading platform for detecting and remediating exposed secrets.

tools.name: TruffleHog
tools.assessment: Open-source tool for finding secrets in git repositories.

tools.name: GitHub Secret Scanning
tools.assessment: Built-in secrets detection with good accuracy and GitHub integration.

qualities.name: Maintainability
qualities.description: The effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be modified by its intended maintainers.
qualities.examples: modularization, design patterns, tidy code, code structures, documentation

ideation.assessment: The green rating reflects the fact that AI is excellent at suggesting design patterns and code structures that improve maintainability.

limitation.name: Limited self-documenting and self-designing systems
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically generate a complete and accurate system design and documentation from code alone.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging but achievable goal. There are already tools that can generate documentation from code, but they are not yet capable of generating a complete and accurate design.

practice.name: Suggesting design patterns and code structures
practice.description: AI can analyze code and suggest design patterns and code structures that will improve its maintainability.
practice.assessment: This is a strong area for AI. There are many tools available that can provide valuable insights into how to improve the maintainability of code.

planning.assessment: The green rating reflects the fact that AI can generate documentation and create refactoring plans to improve the maintainability of existing code.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous refactoring
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically refactor a system to improve its maintainability without risk of introducing errors.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the system's architecture and the ability to reason about the impact of changes.

practice.name: AI-assisted documentation generation and refactoring planning
practice.description: AI automatically generates documentation from code, creates refactoring plans, generates docstrings, README files, and API documentation from code structure and context. Strong area for reducing documentation overhead, though may miss important context in complex systems.
practice.assessment: AI is strong at generating documentation and refactoring plans, saving significant developer time and effort. AI-generated docs are generally accurate for straightforward code but may miss important context or nuance in complex systems requiring human review.

tools.name: Mintlify
tools.assessment: Modern documentation tool that generates docs from code with AI assistance.

tools.name: Swimm
tools.assessment: Documentation tool that keeps docs in sync with code using AI.

tools.name: GitHub Copilot
tools.description: AI pair programmer with documentation features
tools.assessment: Code assistant that can generate inline documentation and comments.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can refactor code, ensuring the changes are correct and don't introduce regressions still requires human oversight.

limitation.name: Cannot guarantee regression-free refactoring
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically refactor code to improve its maintainability without introducing regressions.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. While there are tools that can automate some refactoring tasks, they are not yet capable of handling all of them automatically. Human oversight is still required to ensure that the changes are correct and do not introduce regressions.

practice.name: AI-powered code quality and technical debt management
practice.description: AI automatically refactors code, reviews pull requests, identifies code smells, suggests improvements, detects bugs, provides context-aware feedback on best practices, analyzes code complexity and duplication to identify technical debt hotspots, and prioritizes refactoring by impact. Rapidly maturing for code review, effective for technical debt quantification.
practice.assessment: AI code review is increasingly sophisticated at detecting issues but still misses subtle architectural and business logic errors. Automated refactoring is useful but not comprehensive, requiring human oversight for correctness and regression prevention. AI effectively quantifies technical debt and provides valuable prioritization guidance, though final decisions should consider business priorities.

tools.name: Codium
tools.description: AI-powered code review and testing tool
tools.assessment: Advanced code analysis tool with automated review suggestions.

tools.name: CodeRabbit
tools.assessment: Automated pull request review with context-aware feedback.

tools.name: Amazon CodeGuru
tools.assessment: AWS service for automated code review and performance recommendations.

tools.name: SonarQube
tools.assessment: Industry-standard static analysis platform with debt tracking.

tools.name: CodeScene
tools.assessment: Unique tool that analyzes code evolution to identify technical debt hotspots.

tools.name: Stepsize
tools.assessment: Collaborative tool for tracking and prioritizing technical debt.

qualities.name: Flexibility
qualities.description: The degree to which a system can be adapted for different or evolving hardware, software, or other operational and usage environments.
qualities.examples: infrastructure abstraction, configuration externalization, container orchestration

ideation.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can be a useful tool for identifying potential flexibility issues, it often lacks the deep understanding of the system's specific requirements to suggest the most appropriate solutions.

limitation.name: Limited self-adapting systems
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically adapt a system to changes in its environment without predefined adaptation rules.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging research problem. While there are some examples of self-adapting systems, they are not yet widely used and are often limited to specific types of changes.

practice.name: Suggesting flexible architectures and design patterns
practice.description: AI can analyze a system's architecture and suggest ways to improve its flexibility.
practice.assessment: AI can be a useful tool for identifying potential flexibility issues, but it often lacks the deep understanding of the system's specific requirements to suggest the most appropriate solutions.

planning.assessment: The green rating reflects the fact that AI can excel at creating plans for containerization and infrastructure abstraction, which are key to flexibility.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous infrastructure management
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically provision and manage the infrastructure for a system without oversight.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging but achievable goal. There are already tools that can automate many infrastructure management tasks, but they are not yet capable of handling all of them automatically.

practice.name: AI-assisted infrastructure as code and configuration management
practice.description: AI generates IaC scripts for tools like Terraform and CloudFormation, reverse-engineers infrastructure into code, validates configurations for best practices, and suggests improvements for security and efficiency. Strong area for automation, though complex multi-region deployments may require human refinement.
practice.assessment: AI excels at generating IaC, automating tedious infrastructure work, and detecting common misconfigurations, saving significant devops time and effort. AI is effective at reverse-engineering and standardizing infrastructure patterns. However, complex scenarios require human expertise.

tools.name: Firefly
tools.description: Cloud asset management and IaC generation
tools.assessment: Modern tool for discovering and codifying cloud infrastructure.

tools.name: env0
tools.assessment: Collaborative IaC platform with policy enforcement.

tools.name: Pulumi
tools.description: Infrastructure as code using programming languages
tools.assessment: Modern IaC platform with AI-assisted code generation.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can assist in creating and managing containerized deployments, a deep understanding of the underlying infrastructure is still required for complex scenarios.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous application deployment
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically deploy and manage an application in a production environment without human validation.
limitation.assessment: This is a challenging task for AI. It requires a deep understanding of the application's dependencies and the production environment.

practice.name: AI-powered infrastructure optimization and deployment management
practice.description: AI automatically manages containerized application lifecycles including scaling, healing, and updating, and analyzes workloads across cloud providers to recommend optimal resource allocation, reserved instances, and workload placement for cost efficiency. Emerging for container orchestration, mature for multi-cloud cost optimization.
practice.assessment: AI can automate many deployment tasks but cannot handle all scenarios automatically - complex deployments require human oversight and deep infrastructure understanding. Multi-cloud cost optimization is mature with data-driven recommendations, though implementing changes requires careful consideration of vendor lock-in and migration risks.

tools.name: Kubernetes
tools.description: Container orchestration platform with AI operators
tools.assessment: Industry-standard orchestration with growing AI-driven operator ecosystem.

tools.name: CloudHealth
tools.assessment: Comprehensive cloud cost and governance platform.

tools.name: Spot.io
tools.assessment: AI-powered platform for optimizing spot instance usage.

tools.name: Densify
tools.assessment: Machine learning platform for infrastructure right-sizing.

qualities.name: Safety
qualities.description: The degree to which a product or system avoids harm to people, business, software, property, or a specified context of use.
qualities.examples: Operational constraint, Risk identification, Fail safe, Hazard warning, Safe integration

ideation.assessment: The green rating reflects the fact that AI can be very effective at identifying potential safety hazards and suggesting mitigation strategies during the ideation phase.

limitation.name: Cannot guarantee foolproof safety design
limitation.description: AI cannot design a system that is guaranteed to be safe under all possible conditions.
limitation.assessment: This is an extremely challenging goal. It is impossible to foresee all possible failure modes and to design a system that is completely immune to them.

practice.name: AI-assisted safety analysis and hazard identification
practice.description: AI analyzes system design to identify potential safety hazards like race conditions and deadlocks, helps identify failure modes, assesses severity and likelihood, and suggests mitigation strategies for safety-critical systems. Can accelerate FMEA with suggestions based on similar systems and historical data.
practice.assessment: AI is strong at identifying safety hazards that might be missed by human reviewers and can accelerate FMEA processes. However, domain expertise is essential to ensure completeness, especially for novel system designs and understanding full implications of identified hazards.

tools.name: Relyence
tools.assessment: Comprehensive reliability engineering platform with AI-enhanced analysis.

planning.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can help in creating safety plans and defining fail-safe mechanisms, ensuring the safety of a system in all possible scenarios is a complex task that requires human judgment.

limitation.name: Limited autonomous safety verification
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically verify the safety of a system across all possible states.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging task for AI. It requires the ability to reason about the system's behavior in all possible states and to prove that it will never enter an unsafe state.

practice.name: Creating safety plans and defining fail-safe mechanisms
practice.description: AI can be used to formally verify the correctness of safety-critical systems and to generate safety cases.
practice.assessment: This is a promising but challenging area for AI. Formal verification is a very complex task, and it is not yet possible to fully automate it for large systems.

execution.assessment: The yellow rating reflects the fact that while AI can assist in implementing and testing safety features, the high-stakes nature of safety-critical systems means that human oversight is essential.

limitation.name: Limited self-protecting systems
limitation.description: AI cannot automatically detect and prevent safety hazards in real-time without human oversight.
limitation.assessment: This is a very challenging research problem. While there are some examples of self-protecting systems, they are not yet widely used and are often limited to specific types of hazards.

practice.name: AI-powered safety testing and verification
practice.description: AI generates test cases to verify safety features, injects faults to test resilience, and uses intelligent fuzz testing to trigger edge cases and potential safety violations. Strong for intelligent fuzzing which significantly outperforms random approaches at discovering bugs.
practice.assessment: AI can generate numerous test cases but isn't yet capable of creating the most effective ones for uncovering all safety issues. Intelligent fuzzing is strong but requires extensive runtime and may not cover all failure scenarios in complex systems. High-stakes nature of safety-critical systems means human oversight is essential.

tools.name: Mayhem
tools.assessment: Advanced fuzzing platform with AI-guided test generation.

tools.name: OSS-Fuzz
tools.assessment: Google's fuzzing service for open source projects with extensive coverage.

tools.name: Fuzzbuzz
tools.assessment: Cloud-based fuzzing platform with CI/CD integration.
